comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: References I've come across indicate that Burri was Swiss, not a French national. The name Ernest Burri shows up multiple times at a French-language website about Swiss aviators. I can't read French, but from what I can puzzle out it looks as though he flew for the French during WWI.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: whyaduck: Thanks!  We'll change Burri's nationality in the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 8947617@N06
comment._content: wow the plane in this picture is so different from now days. It is amazing to look at a picture like this and think about how the plane could actually fly. It doesn't seem to safe and the engine must have been very small. Great picture.

comment._content: a horseback pilot! what a metaphor :) Hi, I'm an admin for a group called New Directions, and we'd love to have this photograph added to the group!

comment._content: I wonder what the story is with the split ailerons on the top wing.  For that matter, what model airplane is it?

comment._content: The aircraft was identified on airwarfareforum.com as Henri Farman H.F. 20.
